greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: First differences of A004001.
comment: All the terms are 0 or 1: it is easy to show that if {b(n)} = A004001, b(n)>=b(n-1) and b(n)<n, therefore the first differences form an infinite binary word. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Jun 05 2004
link: R. J. Mathar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..9999
J. Grytczuk, Another variation on Conway's recursive sequence, Discr. Math. 282 (2004), 149-161.
D. Newman, Problem E3274, Amer. Math. Monthly, 95 (1988), 555.
formula: a(n) = 1 if and only if A051135(n+1) = 1.
mathematica: a[1] = a[2] = 1; a[n_] := a[n] = a[a[n - 1]] + a[n - a[n - 1]]; t = Table[a[n], {n, 110}]; Drop[t, 1] - Drop[t, -1] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, May 28 2004 *)
program: (Scheme) (define (A093879 n) (- (A004001 (+ 1 n)) (A004001 n))) ;; Code for A004001 given in that entry. - _Antti Karttunen_, Jan 18 2016
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, May 27 2004
ext: More terms and PARI code from _Klaus Brockhaus_ and _Robert G. Wilson v_, May 27 2004
